Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2012
Award.AbstractNarration:
Viral communities of the Papua New Guinea avifauna

Migratory birds spreading avian flu, bats serving as SARS reservoirs, and the spread of West Nile virus have highlighted the importance of epidemic disease in today's globalized world. Understanding the processes that facilitate disease spread in wildlife is crucial for conservation and human health. Using new and previously collected samples from Papua New Guinea, the evolution and distribution of viruses will be described. High throughput, metagenomic sequencing will be conducted using blood samples and cloacal swabs collected from hundreds of birds across 20 islands. The resulting data will be used to assemble virus genomes and classify viruses. This information along with information on island characteristics (i.e., size, isolation, human disturbance, avian community) will be used to test hypotheses regarding the factors underlying viral evolution and biogeography.

This work will provide critical insights into the importance of variation in geography, human influence, and host species to the spread and distribution of pathogens, and a basis for improving models of disease emergence. In conducting this research, the Fellow will develop new quantitative, computational, and laboratory skills, which will enhance her ability to develop, lead and carry out a multi-faceted, cross-disciplinary research program on wildlife disease ecology. In addition to conducting research, the Fellow will mentor undergraduates through the California Academy of Sciences (CAS) Summer Systematics Institute, and develop skills in teaching the public about science through CAS's museum programs. This project will also provide excellent opportunities for both minority undergraduate students in the Bay Area and Papua New Guinea locals to learn to conduct research, allowing the Fellow to continue to work towards her goal of broadening participation of minorities and women in science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Migratory birds spreading avian flu, bats serving as SARS reservoirs, and the spread of West Nile virus have highlighted the importance of epidemic disease in today's globalized world. Understanding the processes that facilitate disease spread in wildlife is crucial for conservation and human health. Equally vital is knowing what pathogens are present in wildlife. Using high throughput, metagenomic sequencing, I conducted surveys of the pathogens and microbiota (microbiome) present in hundreds of wild birds across numerous species using blood and tissue samples, and cloacal and buccal swabs. Samples were collected from birds across 20 islands in Papua New Guinea, and from birds in North America. I used the resulting data to identify the bacteria and viruses present in these individuals and to investigate the ecological and evolutionary factors underlying microbiome variation. One finding to come out of this work is that microbiome varies substantially with host diet. This suggests that the ecological niche of a species could be an important factor in determining what pathogens a species may be expetced to harbor. In addition, in conducting this work, I discovered a new picornavirus, named poecivirus, which represents a new genus of virus. The presence of this virus is strongly correlated with avian keratin disorder, an emerging epidemic of beak deformities in wild birds. This epidemic of beak deformities appears to be affecting scores of wild avian species globally, and poecivirus is currently the strongest candidate causative agent of this debilitating disorder. Along with collaborators, I am continuing to follow up on this finding to determine definitively if poecivirus is the cause of avian keratin disorder.

During my fellowship tenure, I developed new quantitative, computational, and laboratory skills, established new collaborations and expanded my professional network, which together will provide a strong foundation as I transition to being an independent scientist, leading and carrying out a multi-faceted, cross-disciplinary research program on wildlife disease ecology. As a NSF Postdocotoral Fellow, I presented my research to the scientific community through eight peer-reviewed publications, five contributed conference talks, three contributed poster presentations at scientific conferences, and I was invited to give seminars at eight colleges and universities. In addition, I presented my research to the public through school programs, and through educational programs at the California Academy of Sciences in San Francisco's Golden Gate Park. My work garnered substantial public interest, resulting in coverage in several popular media outlets, including National Geographic, The Associated Press (article and video), Audubon, Journal of Montreal, and Environmental Health News.

In addition to conducting research, the NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship gave me the opportunity to improve my skills in undergraduate teaching and mentorship. During my fellowship tenure, I participated in programs focused on incorporating improved active learning methods into undergraduate science education, and I gained teaching experience in both formal and non-traditional undergraduate education. Furthermore, I mentored undergraduates and early graduate students, including several individuals from groups underrepresented in the sciences, who went on to attend graduate school and/or complete graduate degrees, thereby broadening participation of minorities and women in science.
